clusters.title: ‘At 2am, it feels like someone’s there’: why Nigerians are choosing chatbots to give them advice and therapy
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘At 2am, it feels like someone’s there’: why Nigerians are choosing chatbots to give them advice and therapy

items.title: ‘At 2am, it feels like someone’s there’: why Nigerians are choosing chatbots to give them advice and therapy
items.standfirst: With many unable to access or afford qualified therapists, AI is filling the mental healthcare vacuum, amid calls for tighter regulationOn a quiet evening in her Abuja hotel, Joy Adeboye, 23, sits on her bed clutching her phone, her mind racing and chest tightening. On her screen is yet another abusive message from her stalker – a man she had met nine months earlier at her church.He had asked Adeboye out; when she declined, he began sending her intimidating, insulting and blackmailing messages on social media, as well as spreading false information about her online. There were even death threats. Continue reading...
items.content: With many unable to access or afford qualified therapists, AI is filling the mental healthcare vacuum, amid calls for tighter regulationOn a quiet evening in her Abuja hotel, Joy Adeboye, 23, sits on her bed clutching her phone, her mind racing and chest tightening. On her screen is yet another abusive message from her stalker – a man she had met nine months earlier at her church.He had asked Adeboye out; when she declined, he began sending her intimidating, insulting and blackmailing messages on social media, as well as spreading false information about her online. There were even death threats. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nigerians use chatbots for mental health
Chatbots fill mental healthcare gap
Many cannot access qualified therapists
AI provides alternative therapy option
Regulation of chatbots is necessary

clusters.title: One in 14 children who die in England have closely related parents, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Child mortality linked to consanguineous parents

items.title: One in 14 children who die in England have closely related parents, study finds
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Calls for ‘urgent action’ as study also finds stark ethnic and socio-economic disparities in child mortality and consanguinityOne in 14 children who died in England in a four-year period had parents who were close relatives, according to “stark” figures revealed by the first study of its kind.The figures, published by the National Child Mortality Database (NCMD), based at the University of Bristol, analysed all 13,045 child deaths in England between 2019 and 2023. Of these, 926 (7%) were found to be of children born to consanguineous parents, meaning the mother and father are close blood relatives, such as first cousins. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Calls for ‘urgent action’ as study also finds stark ethnic and socio-economic disparities in child mortality and consanguinityOne in 14 children who died in England in a four-year period had parents who were close relatives, according to “stark” figures revealed by the first study of its kind.The figures, published by the National Child Mortality Database (NCMD), based at the University of Bristol, analysed all 13,045 child deaths in England between 2019 and 2023. Of these, 926 (7%) were found to be of children born to consanguineous parents, meaning the mother and father are close blood relatives, such as first cousins. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Study finds link between child mortality and consanguineous parents
One in 14 child deaths related to consanguineous parents
Ethnic and socio-economic disparities found
Child mortality rates vary by demographic
Consanguineous parents face higher risks

clusters.title: Reading and writing can lower dementia risk by almost 40%, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Reading and writing lower dementia risk

items.title: Reading and writing can lower dementia risk by almost 40%, study finds
items.standfirst: Cognitive health in later life is ‘strongly influenced’ by lifelong exposure to intellectually stimulating environments, say researchers Reading, writing and learning a language or two can lower your risk of dementia by almost 40%, according to a study that suggests millions of people could prevent or delay the condition.Dementia is one of the world’s biggest health threats. The number of people living with the condition is forecast to triple to more than 150 million globally by 2050, and experts say it presents a big and rapidly growing threat to future health and social care systems in every community, country and continent. Continue reading...
items.content: Cognitive health in later life is ‘strongly influenced’ by lifelong exposure to intellectually stimulating environments, say researchers Reading, writing and learning a language or two can lower your risk of dementia by almost 40%, according to a study that suggests millions of people could prevent or delay the condition.Dementia is one of the world’s biggest health threats. The number of people living with the condition is forecast to triple to more than 150 million globally by 2050, and experts say it presents a big and rapidly growing threat to future health and social care systems in every community, country and continent. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Study finds reading and writing reduce dementia risk
Lifelong exposure to intellectually stimulating environments helps
Learning new languages also beneficial
Dementia risk reduced by almost 40%
Cognitive health influenced by lifelong activities

clusters.title: UK law firms consider action on behalf of women who developed brain tumours after using contraceptive
clusters.neutral_headline: UK law firms consider action over brain tumours

items.title: UK law firms consider action on behalf of women who developed brain tumours after using contraceptive
items.standfirst: Studies show Depo-Provera users have much higher relative risk of developing meningiomas, although overall risk remains lowUK law firms are considering legal action on behalf of women who developed brain tumours after using the contraceptive injection Depo-Provera.Depo-Provera is a high-dose synthetic progesterone, prescribed for contraception and other menstrual symptoms, administered via injection every three months. According to UN calculations, 74 million women worldwide and 3.1% of UK women aged 15-49 use injectable contraception. Continue reading...
items.content: Studies show Depo-Provera users have much higher relative risk of developing meningiomas, although overall risk remains lowUK law firms are considering legal action on behalf of women who developed brain tumours after using the contraceptive injection Depo-Provera.Depo-Provera is a high-dose synthetic progesterone, prescribed for contraception and other menstrual symptoms, administered via injection every three months. According to UN calculations, 74 million women worldwide and 3.1% of UK women aged 15-49 use injectable contraception. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Law firms consider action for Depo-Provera users

clusters.title: Top US medical body to review vaccine effectiveness as government ‘abdicates’ responsibility
clusters.neutral_headline: Top US medical body to review vaccine effectiveness

items.title: Top US medical body to review vaccine effectiveness as government ‘abdicates’ responsibility
items.standfirst: AMA to review safety of respiratory vaccines as health agencies end recommendations based on no new dataThe largest medical organization in the US will help conduct a review on the safety and effectiveness of respiratory vaccines as federal health agencies and advisers end vaccine recommendations based on no new information.“They are filling a void that the government created,” Ezekiel Emanuel, vice-provost for global initiatives at the University of Pennsylvania, told journalists on Tuesday. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Psychiatric drugs aren’t always the answer | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Psychiatric drugs not always the answer

items.title: Psychiatric drugs aren’t always the answer | Letter
items.standfirst: Talking therapies have made huge progress and should be more widely available, writes Ann Marie TaylorYes, there has been a shocking lack of progress in developing transformative psychiatric medicine (We need new drugs for mental ill-health, 5 February), but this may be because in mental health, drugs are not always the answer (see, for example, Richard P Bentall’s Doctoring the Mind).Huge progress has been made in the effectiveness of talking therapies – for example, free effective treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is available to all UK army veterans through the charity PTSD Resolution. Continue reading...
items.content: Talking therapies have made huge progress and should be more widely available, writes Ann Marie TaylorYes, there has been a shocking lack of progress in developing transformative psychiatric medicine (We need new drugs for mental ill-health, 5 February), but this may be because in mental health, drugs are not always the answer (see, for example, Richard P Bentall’s Doctoring the Mind).Huge progress has been made in the effectiveness of talking therapies – for example, free effective treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is available to all UK army veterans through the charity PTSD Resolution. Continue reading...

clusters.title: FDA declines to review Moderna application for new flu vaccine
clusters.neutral_headline: FDA declines to review Moderna application for new flu vaccine

items.title: FDA declines to review Moderna application for new flu vaccine
items.standfirst: Moderna requests meeting to discuss refusal as decision could have implications for all new and updated vaccinesUS regulators will not review Moderna’s request to license a new, potentially more effective flu shot – even though the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) previously gave the green light to the project – in a decision that could have implications for all new and updated vaccines in the US.It’s the latest move by the Trump administration against vaccines. Officials in January decided to stop fully recommending one-third of routine childhood vaccines, including flu vaccines. Continue reading...
items.content: Moderna requests meeting to discuss refusal as decision could have implications for all new and updated vaccinesUS regulators will not review Moderna’s request to license a new, potentially more effective flu shot – even though the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) previously gave the green light to the project – in a decision that could have implications for all new and updated vaccines in the US.It’s the latest move by the Trump administration against vaccines. Officials in January decided to stop fully recommending one-third of routine childhood vaccines, including flu vaccines. Continue reading...

ai_summary: FDA refused to review Moderna's new flu vaccine application
Decision may have implications for new and updated vaccines
Moderna requested a meeting to discuss the refusal
FDA previously approved the project for development
Decision could impact vaccine development in the US
